documents.title: end-of-day round-up
text: this liveblog is coming to a close now here are some key links to this story , and some further reading : mps have voted by 524 votes to 43 a government majority of 481 to join the us-led coalition taking part in air strikes against islamic state ( isis ) in iraq .
uk air strikes against isis in iraq : the best-case and worst-case scenarios .
labour mp rushanara ali resigns from the opposition front bench and abstains ; her colleague iain mckenzie is sacked after voting against the air strikes .
cameron promises patience and persistence , not shock and awe john crace 's commons sketch .
anti-war protesters outside the palace of westminster as mps voted in favour of air strikes .

mitchell/barcroft media patrick wintour , the guardian 's political editor , files this report on today 's vote : britain embarked on a renewed war in the middle east starting with air strikes in the next 48 hours , after mps overwhelmingly sanctioned a uk air assault against islamic state ( isis ) targets in iraq .

cabinet ministers also told the commons that isis will ultimately only be crushed if the terrorist group is pursued to its bases inside syria , signalling an eventual widening of conflict that is expected to last several years .
the scale of david cameron 's victory was predictable as soon as he reached an agreement with ed miliband establishing that a separate request would be put to mps to sanction any action in syria .

downing street stressed that six tornado jets would be in the skies over iraq very shortly , adding the commons has sanctioned uk military advisers being sent to iraq to train the iraqi army , and act as target setters for the raf .
there are already early signs that is has switched tactics to minimise its exposure by reducing roadblocks , the use of trucks and placing is black flags in civilian areas .
that 's it for the liveblog for now from me , claire phipps .
should there be any later developments , a colleague is on hand to update this liveblog .
thanks for reading and for your comments .
following the vote the defence secretary , michael fallon , said there would not be a speedy resolution to the isis crisis : you will not see an immediate series of particular hits .
this is going to be a long campaign of weeks and probably months to drive out is [ isis ] .
we will be very careful to avoid civilian casualties .
each of these missions will have to be personally authorised by me and there are clear rules of engagement .
british prime minister david cameron leaves the houses of parliament after mps voted overwhelmingly in favour of joining us-led air strikes .
tallis /afp/getty images

my colleague ewen macaskill provides this assessment of the best-case and worst-case scenarios for british involvement in the air strikes campaign : best-case scenarios air strikes contain isis , creating space for regional states to work out a solution .
iraq 's forces , with the peshmerga , regain northern iraq .
the new iraqi government works for sunnis as well as shia .
in syria , the free syrian army takes control of the rebel-held area and reaches agreement with president bashar al-assad .
a new government is formed and assad goes .
only a little if any of this is likely to happen .
worst-case scenarios iraq breaks up into three separate pieces kurds in the north , sunnis in the centre and the shias in the south .
isis retains control of the sunni areas of iraq as well as north-east syria , and expands into jordan .
iran becomes even more involved in the region .
turkey too is drawn in .
the bombing by the us , britain and france results in blowback that sees terrorist attacks in britain , france and the us .
you can read the full verdict here .

nicholas watt sends this handy totting-up of how the votes were cast : yes votes total : 524 + 2 tellers ( including yes vote of rushanara ali who voted in both divisions to register abstention ) conservative : 275 labour : 191 liberal democrat : 47 democratic unionist party : 8 independent : 2 alliance : 1 yes tellers : 2 no votes total : 43 + 2 tellers ( including no vote of rushanara ali who voted in both divisions to register abstention ) labour : 24 conservative : 6 scottish national party : 5 sdlp ( social democratic and labour party ) : 3 plaid cymru : 2 liberal democrat : 1 green : 1 respect : 1 no tellers : 2 a total of 570 mps voted or acted as tellers out of the 639 mps eligible to vote .
there are 650 mps .
the speaker and his three deputies do not vote , the five sinn fein mps have not taken their seats and there are two vacant seats .

documents.title: mps who voted against the motion
text: here are the mps who voted against the motion , or who backed the noes by acting as tellers .

labour ( 24 votes against , plus 1 teller ) the labour mps who voted against were : diane abbott , graham allen , anne begg , ronnie campbell , martin caton , katy clark , ian davidson , paul flynn , stephen hepburn , kate hoey , kelvin hopkins , sian james , mark lazraowicz , john mcdonnell , iain mckenzie , austin mitchell , grahame morris , george mudie , linda riordan , barry sheerman , dennis skinner , graham stringer , and mike wood .
there was also one labour teller , jeremy corbyn , and one labour mp who voted against , but also voted in favour ( ie , actively abstained ) , rushanara ali .

conservatives ( 6 votes against ) the conservatives who voted against were : richard bacon , john baron , gordon henderson , adam holloway , nigel mills and mark reckless lib dems ( 1 vote against ) julian huppert sdlp ( 3 votes against ) the sdlp mps who voted against were : mark durkan , alasdair mcdonnell and margaret ritchie .

plaid cymru ( 2 votes against ) the plaid mps who voted against were : jonathan edwards and hywel williams respect ( 1 vote against ) george gallway snp ( 5 votes against , plus 1 teller ) the snp mps who voted against were : stewart hosie , angus roberton , mike weir , eilidh whiteford and angus brendan mcneill .
the teller was mike wishart .
greens ( 1 vote against ) caroline lucas
chuck hagel continues : coalition forces will continue to maintain pressure on isil forces throughout iraq .
this coalition continues to expand .
belgium , denmark and the netherlands have signed up in the past two days , he says : a few minutes ago ¦ i spoke with the british defence minister , michael fallon .
he informed me the british parliament had just voted to join the air campaig in iraq with the us and our coalition partners .
we appreciate all the contributions and commitment of our friends and allies .

documents.title: iain mckenzie sacked as parliamentary aide for voting against air strikes
text: as predicted by nicholas watt , labour mp iain mckenzie has been sacked as parliamentary aide to the shadow defence secretary vernon coaker for voting against the motion : mark ferguson ( @ markfergusonuk ) iain mckenzie - pps to vernon coaker and margaret curran - has been sacked for opposing airstrikes in iraq

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: here 's an afternoon summary .
mps have voted to back air strikes against islamic state ( isis ) in iraq by a majority of 481 .
only 43 mps voted against the motion , which was tabled by the government but supported by labour on a three-line whip .
as a result the first british air strikes , involving up to six tornado jets based in cyprus , could take place very soon .
but michael fallon , the defence secretary , that people should not expect immediate shock and awe because the campaign was going to proceed slowly .
and the first strikes could be very limited , he suggested .
this is going to be a long campaign weeks and probably months to push [ isis } back and to see it defeated in iraq .
so you will not see an immediate series of particular hits or whatever .
many mps have expressed reservations about allowing britain to conduct air strikes against isis in syria .
in many ways the most interesting debate taking place today was the one on the option specifically not included in the motion ( see 9.23am ) - air strikes against targets in syria .
in his speech david cameron said there was a strong case for attacking isis in syria and philip hammond , the foreign secretary , and fallon have both been talking up the prospect this happening .

but ed miliband , the labour leader , said he had serious reservations about bombing targets in syria ( see 12.16pm ) and speeches during the debate made it clear that it would be hard for him to get labour to back a syrian campaign without facing a significant revolt .
some tories mps also said they were opposed to any form of mission creep that could lead to britain bombing syria .

given the importance that miliband has always placed on keeping his party united , and given the difficulty cameron would have winning a vote on military intervention without labour support ( as he discovered last year ) , on the basis of today 's debate the chances of parliament voting to allow the raf to bomb syria seems slight .
rushanara ali has explained why she has resigned from labour 's frontbench over the the iraq vote .
( see 5.38pm . )
i am not confident that this military action will be effective in the short term in just targeting the terrorists and not harming innocent civilians , she said in a letter to ed miliband .

nor can i pretend to have any confidence that there is a credible long-term strategy to build up the capacity of the iraqi army or that the potential impact on radicalisation in the uk has been properly thought through .

also , the labour mp iain mckenzie has sacked as a pps to the shadow defence secretary for voting against the party whip ( although some of us never knew the shadow defence secretary had a pps in the first place . )
we should get a voting list with the full names of those voting against the motion soon .
the snp 's angus robertson voted against the motion and tells the bbc he does n't think scotland would have voted for air strikes .
it shows that very little has been learned from previous conflicts ¦ there was no plan then [ 2003 ] and there 's no plan now .
he argues that the motion makes no mention of diplomatic efforts or a long-term plan for dealing with isis .

documents.title: rushanara ali resignation statement
text: rushanara ali has put out a statement about her resignation from the opposition front bench .
the quotes are via press association .
in a letter to labour leader ed miliband ahead of the vote , ali wrote : i understand the case that has been made and will not be voting against the motion .
but i am unable in conscience to support the motion and i will make a deliberate abstention .
there can be no doubt that the actions of isil are horrific and barbaric and i share the revulsion that everyone in our country feels towards them .
however , i am not confident that this military action will be effective in the short term in just targeting the terrorists and not harming innocent civilians .

nor can i pretend to have any confidence that there is a credible long-term strategy to build up the capacity of the iraqi army or that the potential impact on radicalisation in the uk has been properly thought through .

despite good intentions , too many mistakes have been made over the last decade and far too many people in conflict zones have had to pay a high price for misconceived actions by the uk and other countries .
i appreciate the sincerity of members of parliament from all sides of the house who today support military action against isil .
i know that british muslims stand united in the total condemnation of the murders that isil have committed .
however , there is a genuine belief in muslim and non-muslim communities that military action will only create further bloodshed and further pain for the people of iraq .
ali said she was standing down with great regret and told miliband she remained totally committed to your leadership .

in a letter of reply , miliband praised ali as someone with great ability and talent and said he regretted her departure from his frontbench team , but added : i respect your decision and accept your resignation .

my colleague nicholas watt sends this quick take on the vote : parliament has voted overwhelmingly in favour of supporting british air strikes against targets from the islamic state ( isis ) in iraq .
at the end of a debate lasting nearly seven hours , mps voted by 524 to 43 a government majority of 481 to authorise military strikes against targets in iraq .
the rebels included a familiar array of mps on both sides of the house , including the tory former army office john baron and the labour former shadow public health minister diane abbott .
the only surprise rebel was iain mckenzie , the labour mp for inverclyde , who is likely to be sacked as parliamentary aide to the shadow defence secretary vernon coaker .
mps on all sides of the house delivered impassioned speeches during the debate that started at 10.30am .
even supporters of the government motion spoke of their unease about embarking on the third military campaign in iraq since 1991 .
the motion was carefully crafted to limit the strikes to iraq .
but prime minister david cameron held out the possibility of extending the strikes to syria .
there are still a few protestors outside the houses of parliament following the vote : cameramanjimitv ( @ cameramanjimitv ) very few protestors outside parliament after the vote .
they 're quite noisy though .
mark reckless , a conservative mp , says on twitter that he voted against the government .
mark reckless mp ( @ markreckless ) i voted against bombing isil in iraq .
a year ago we were asked to bomb other side in syria +what good did 557 mps voting to attack libya do ?

documents.title: air strikes : what happens next ?
text: a reminder of this earlier post about what will happen now that british mps have voted to support air strikes in iraq .

the first attacks against islamic state ( isis ) targets in iraq could come within hours , reports the guardian 's defence and intelligence correspondent , ewen macaskill : the jets , based in cyprus , were out over iraq on wednesday night gathering intelligence in preparation for the attack an exercise that has been ongoing in the past month .
british special forces are already deployed to the region , primarily to gather intelligence and to help identify targets .
they are liaising with the 190,000-strong kurdish peshmerga , the main force on the ground engaged against isis in iraq .
six tornado jets are based at akrotiri , in cyprus , and that is seen within the mod as sufficient at this stage , a commitment that will not stretch limited resources .
in libya , the raf had 16 tornadoes in action and 10 typhoons .
also involved is an raf rivet joint surveillance plane , based in qatar .
a royal air force ( raf ) tornado gr4 fighter bomber at raf akrotiri , cyprus ( in 2009 ) .
macdiarmid/getty images the six gr4-type tornado aircraft have been in cyprus for around six weeks ; they are usually based at raf marham in norfolk .
when taking part in any potential air strikes , they will come under the command of us centcom ( central command ) .
rushanara ali , the shadow education minister who resigned over the vote , did not actually vote against the government , the bbc reports .
she just abstained .
she is mp for bethnal green and bow , the seat that used to be held by george galloway .
it 's in london 's east end and has a very large muslim population ( around 35 % ) .
it is unusual to resign over an issue like this when you are abstaining , and not voting against the party whip .
given that the government was going to get a huge majority , the labour whips could easily have found an excuse for her to be absent .
but i presume ali wants her constituents to know that she did not back military action .
rushanara ali has resigned from the opposition front bench , which supported the government motion to begin air strikes in iraq , in order to abstain .
she re-took her seat in bethnal green & bow for labour in 2010 , after george galloway had scooped it for respect in 2005 on an anti-war ticket .
rushanara ali in 2010 after she won the bethnal green and bow seat .
dempsey/pa
the labour whips says the rebels include 24 labour mps , five tories and two lib dems .
labour whips ( @ labourwhips ) looks like of the 43 noes 5 tories , 2 lib dems and 24 labour

text: the government has won .
for : 524 against : 43 government majority : 481

mps are voting in the commons now .

not long to find out .

jameslyons ( @ sw1james ) around 25 labour rebels
labour 's john mcdonnell is another mp who was not called to speak .
john mcdonnell ( @ johnmcdonnellmp ) sat all day in commons but never got called to speak in iraq debate.what happened to democracy & balanced debate .
disgusted .
the tellers for the ayes ( those backing the government ) are mark hunter , a lib dem , and gavin barwell , a conservative .
the tellers for the noes are jeremy corbyn , a labour mp , and pete wishart , an snp mp .
asked if it would have been better to have had a un resolution , clegg says that 's not necessary for the action to be legal .
and other security council members have made it clear they are opposed .
labour 's robert flello ( who did not get called in the debate - see 4.35pm ) says he will vote with a very heavy heart .
will the government keep the house informed on developments .
clegg says he understands how flello feels ; other mps feel the same way .
and that 's it .
mps are now voting .
clegg says he supports something labour 's shabana mahmood said in the debate ; she said islamic state was neither islamic , nor a state .
caroline lucas , the green mp , asks clegg if he thinks that all diplomatic options have been exhausted .
clegg says there are time when it is simply impossible to reason with your foe .
this is a barbaric outfit ; it can not be reasoned with , he says .
in fact , president obama has shown great restraint .
he has assembled a coalition , and waited for a request from iraq .
clare short , the former labour cabinet minister who resigned over the decision to go to war in iraq in 2003 , has been speaking to sky news about today 's debate .

she does not seem convinced by declarations by ed miliband and others that the current situation is not the same as that faced a decade ago : here we go again ¦ throwing six planes into it to go along with the us and be a poodle again .
there 's no strategy here .
it wo n't solve anything .
we need more intelligence about the underlying problems and how we 're going to address them .
short said she is not opposed to using some military force to prevent the spread of isis , but said the issues over palestine , saudi arabia and iran needed to be addressed in tandem .
she said the most poisonous version of islam is coming from saudi arabia .
air strikes , she added , make it more likely we will get bombs on the streets of london , not less likely .
clegg says the government is not pretending that air strikes on their own are a solution .
the government is not inactive in syria , he says .
it is training and supporting opposition forces in syria .
some 60 nations are involved in the coalition against isis .
britain is doing what it can do best .
just because you can not do everything , that does n't mean you should do nothing .
asked what role the royal navy will play , clegg says the navy has several vessels in the gulf , and submarines with tomahawk missiles .

documents.title: nick clegg 's speech
text: nick clegg is now winding up for the government .
john mcdonnell , the labour mp , asks if he agrees with david cameron that the government should not have to get a second vote to take action in syria .
clegg says cameron was just making the point that sometimes a government needs to act in an emergency .
nick clegg commends the motion to the house of commons .
/bbc
alexander says degrading isis must be in the service of creating new forms of government in iraq .
military action must be under-pinned by a clear political strategy , he says .
he says that mps can not see for certain all that lies ahead .
there is the possibility of unforeseen and uncertain consequences , he says .
alexander says it is wholly unclear who would conduct ground operations in syria .
although labour wants a un security council resolution , it is not making that a pre-condition for backing action in syria , he says .
however , any approach should be cautious and calibrated .
sir richard ottaway , a conservative , asks for clarification .
what would labour do if russia vetoed a un resolution ?
alexander says labour will not allow its moral compass to be set in moscow or beijing .
a un resolution would not be a pre-condition .
but it would be worth trying to get a resolution , he says .

documents.title: douglas alexander 's speech
text: douglas alexander , the shadow foreign secretary , is now winding up for labour .
he says backing the motion has been a wrenching decision for the party .
but it is not taking this decision just to support the government , or the military .

it is doing so because the action meets the six criteria set by ed miliband : have just cause ; be a last resort ; be legal ; have a reasonable prospect of success ; have regional support ; and be proportionate .
douglas alexander , shadow foreign secretary , speaks in favour of the motion .
/bbc
labour 's barry gardiner says david cameron says we are fighting for democracy .
but the countries were are supporting in the region are not democracies .
they are theocratic autocracies .
we support them at our peril , he says .
the labour mp robert flello says on twitter that , after waiting all day , he does n't think he will be called .
rob flello mp ( @ robflellomp ) very frustrated that having been in # isil # airstrikes debate all day looks v. unlikely will be called ( & 3mins allowed only ! )
undemocratic
labour 's hugh bayley says engaging militarily is the least worst option .
jesse norman , a conservative , says he is concerned about parliament giving pre-authorisation for military action in the way that it is doing today .
these should be decisions for the executive , and the commons should be able to hold it to account afterwards .
if the commons has agreed military action in advance , minister can always says it was your decision if things go wrong .
when the commons met on a saturday before the falklands war , it did not vote for war , he says .
it just debated an adjournment motion .
norman says that in time the government will see the attractions of going back to that model .

documents.title: six of the best backbench speeches
text: the debate will end at 5pm , and the time allotted for backbench speeches is almost over .
there have been plenty of good speeches .
here are six of the best backbench ones .
george galloway pat mcfadden kenneth clarke adam holloway ian austin sir edward leigh
my colleague nicholas watt has filed this report on respect mp george galloway 's intervention in the commons debate .
( see here for more on the speech and a video clip . )

george galloway was accused of making a disgraceful intervention in the house of commons debate on iraq when the respect mp said the islamic state was controlling an area the size of britain because of a quiescent local population .
galloway prompted the angriest exchanges of the debate when he told mps : isil itself is an imaginary army .
a former defence secretary said we must bomb their bases .
they do n't have any bases .
the territory they control is the size of britain and yet there is only between 10-20,000 of them .
do the maths .
they do n't concentrate as an army .
they do n't live in bases .
the only way a force of that size could successfully hold the territory that they hold is if they have a population which is acting as the water in which they are swimming .
and that population is quiescent because of western policies and western invasion and occupation .
that 's the truth of the matter .
isil could not survive for five minutes if the tribes in the west of iraq rose up against them .

ian austin , the former labour minister , interrupted galloway to say : does he understand how appalled people will be to hear him say that women buried alive , women enslaved , are quiescent in their persecution by these people ?
galloway replied to austin : they do n't like it up them .
they 'd rather have an imaginary debate moving around imaginary armies .
isil is a death cult , it is a gang of terrorist murderers .
it is not an army and it is certainly not an army that is going to be destroyed by aerial bombardment .
isil is able to rule the parts of iraq that it does because nobody in those parts has any confidence in the government in baghdad , a sectarian government .
respect mp george galloway outside the houses of parliament today .
kitwood/getty images
mark reckless , a conservative , says mps should be modest and humble when they vote today .
he says he would like to know whether david cameron now believes the 2003 iraq war was a mistake .
labour 's diane abbott is speaking now .
she says that , in his speech , david cameron virtually admitted that he wanted to launch air strikes against isis in syria .
and he hinted that he could act without a commons vote on the pretext of a humanitarian intervention , she says .
she says this reminds her of 2003 .
she will not support the motion because she can not see the strategy , and she can not see the exit strategy .
sky 's faisal islam thinks up to 70 mps could vote against the government .
faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) confirmation the snp/ plaid cymru will vote against today 's isil motion currently looking at 60-70 votes against and plenty abstentions
richard bacon , a conservative , says britain has been dropping bombs on iraq for two thirds of his adult lifetime .
each time , we think this will make things better , he says .
but in fact each time it makes it worse .
he says he finds it hard to accept ed miliband 's argument that britain needs to intervene to encourage arab countries to intervene .
the largest 18 muslim countries , of which 13 are arab , have 2.8m soldiers , he says .
they should be intervening .
islam faces its own version of the 30 years war .
the idea that can get involved and support one side is delusional , he says .
on his blog nick robinson considers what will happen next .
he says government supporters think that the liberation of mosul from isis later this year could persuade people to back air strikes against isis in syria .
many mps said there was no military or strategic logic in attacking targets in iraq but not syria when the border between the two now no longer really exists .

one well-placed source told me that attitudes to strikes on syria would change once people saw the success of action of the ground in iraq - the first target , i was told , was the fall of mosul in late october or november .
paul flynn , a labour mp , says today 's motion is the thin end of a bloody and ugly wedge that will lead to mission creep and see britain sucked into war with unpleasant consequences .

documents.title: lord hutton of furness 's speech
text: earlier in the lords lord hutton of furness , the former labour defence secretary john hutton , said that , if air strikes against isis in iraq went ahead , the government would have to rethink its position on air strikes in syria .
and it should not rule out committing ground forces too , he said .
we should n't rule out the deployment , if necessary , of uk ground forces to support our allies in the region .
i hope it does n't come to that .
but i think it would be a very great mistake to signal to our enemy in advance the limits we are prepared to place now on the sort of support we might be prepared to give to our allies .
we have to win this campaign and do whatever is necessary to destroy the evil is represents .
jackie doyle-prince , a conservative mp , has praised his stance .
jackie doyle-price ( @ jackiedp ) pleased to see lord hutton showing more sense than the labour leadership on syria .
like the snp , plaid cymru , the welsh nationalist party , is also voting against the motion .
plaid cymru ( @ plaid cymru ) plaid cymru urges region-led response to iraq crisis : mps will vote against air strikes # iraq # plaidcymru there are three plaid cymru mps and six snp mps .

documents.title: farage : 'bombing will make the streets of britain less safe '
text: nigel farage is speaking at ukip 's party conference in doncaster right now .
his speech has just turned to the debate taking place in the commons at the same time .

whether he believes it or not , he could not resist a dig about the timing of the parliamentary recall , which clashes with what ukip might have expected to be its moment in the spotlight : i 'm not going to speculate on the timing of that ¦ the day after mr carswell [ douglas carswell , former conservative mp who defected to ukip ] joined us , we were told the nation was in a state of emergency , so i 'm not surprised .
if starting the bombing mission was that important , why could n't they start [ the debate ] yesterday ?
( the state of emergency was in fact the uk terror threat being raised from substantial to severe . )
ukip leader nigel farage delivers his keynote speech at the ukip annual conference in doncaster .
fuller/pa farage urges caution about the proposed air strikes campaign , after the government lost a vote on intervention in syria last year .
many of those rebels we were planning to support then could turn out to to be those we will be bombing on saturday , he says : our foreign policy has been a total and utter shambles .
you can not win wars just by bombing ¦ you will necessarily kill a large number of civilians in doing so .

once again we are entering into military action without thinking through what we 're going to do afterwards , farage adds : i suspect it will make the streets of britain less safe than they are today .
john baron , a conservative , says some key questions remain unanswered .
there is a lack of a coordinated plan , he says .
as a solider ( baron was a captain in the royal regiment of fusiliers ) , it was important to clear objectives , he says .
there is a danger isis will be able to spin that they withstood an assault from the west .
mike gapes , a labour mp , says isis is not islamic , and it is not a state .
he would like the media not to use that name , and he is glad that the motion does not use it .
here 's the web page showing today 's commons hansard .
as i write , it has a full transcript of the debate up until 12.30pm , when nigel dodds was speaking .
as the day goes on , it will be updated .
generally transcripts of speeches go up three hours after they were delivered .
and here 's the lords hansard .
it also currently goes up to 12.30pm , when lord hurd was speaking .
angus robertson , the snp , says people are right to be sceptical .
in the past we have heard strong arguments for intervention .
but very little has been said about what will happen next .
he says today 's motion does support bombing .
but it does not say anything about what will be done to construct peace .
that is why he and the snp will be voting against the motion , he says .
labour 's jeremy corbyn says this is the third time has been asked to vote for war in iraq .
he says he will not be backing the government .
the government should reflect more on the damage its previous interventions have caused , he says .
julian lewis , a conservative , says he said before today that he would only support the government if it had a strategy for forces on the ground to follow up the success of air strikes .
the prime minister said iraqi and kurdish forces would play this role , lewis says .
he says he would like to see the involvement of other arab countries .
nevertheless , he says he will support the government reluctantly .
the time limit for speeches has now been cut to three minutes .
rory stewart , the conservative mp and the new chair of the commons defence committee , backs the motion .
but he says he is glad that mps have been wary of making claims about what can be achieved in terms for destroying isis .
all the mps who have spoken about the need for a political solution and a diplomatic solution must be right , he says .

while british mps have been debating the decision to join air strikes in iraq , my colleague haroon siddique reports that four islamic state ( isis ) tanks in the eastern syrian province of deir el-zour have been hit by us strikes : us central command said 10 air strikes were carried out in iraq and syria targeting the extremist group on thursday and friday .
us central command 's announcement came hours after a uk-based monitoring group , the syrian observatory for human rights , said isis bases and oilfields had been hit in overnight sorties .

the us military said that in iraq it wiped out three isis humvees as well as another vehicle with five air strikes in kirkuk , in the north , while an air strike west of baghdad destroyed a guard shack , armed vehicle and bunker .
another air strike destroyed four armed vehicles , an isis command and control node and a checkpoint in qaim , in north-west iraq , near the syrian border .
there were three strikes in deir al-zour , eastern syria , where us-led forces started bombing isis militants on tuesday .
a usnavy f-18e super hornet receives fuel from a kc-135 stratotanker over northern iraq after conducting air strikes .
sgt .

shawn nickel/ap turkey has also raised the prospect of joining the international coalition , with the turkish prime minister , ahmet davutoglu , telling a meeting of his ruling party in ankara : if any military operation or a solution carries the perspective of bringing peace and stability to the region , we will support it .
we will take whatever measures our national security requires .
cheryl gillan , the conservative former welsh secretary , says she will support the government today .
but she says she does not want britain to be sucked into a never-ending war .
several mps have criticised george galloway following his speech , huffington post reports .

documents.title: sir edward leigh 's speech
text: sir edward leigh , a conservative , says bombing only in iraq makes no military sense .
and britain does not have enough military assets , he says .
never have so few been asked by so many to achieve so much with no clear aim in sight .
if you want to act with a big stick in the world , you must wield the means and what have we been doing to the armed forces over the last four years , and how many planes have we got to bomb isil ?
what serious difference will we make the truth is up to now we have done everything wrong .
in our zealous liberalism we have encouraged revolutions across the middle east and then been profoundly shocked when the forces we have helped unleash have turned against us .
in that sense the british government is indirectly culpable in fostering the conditions for a jihadism to thrive in iraq and syria we are where we are .
we have caused this mess and we should apologise to the people of the region for it .
he says he has visited iraq , and talked to people under threat .
therefore , although he has severe doubts about what this will achieve , he will vote for the government with a heavy heart and foreboding .
michael meacher , the labour leftwinger , is backing the government motion .
this is about intervening in response to a request from the iraqi government .
it is not the same as 2004 .
and isis is a monster with a bloodlust , he says .
it is comparable to the mongols under genghis khan , or the nazis , he says .
but he warns about the dangers of intervention .
iraq needs to be restored to a viable state , he says .
the only justification for military action is to buy the time to enable the reconstruction of the broken iraqi state , he says .
( meacher has set out this argument in a post on his blog . )
john bercow , the speaker , says he is going to cut the time limit on speeches from five minutes to four minutes to try to ensure everyone who wants can speak .
dominic grieve , the conservative former attorney general , is speaking now .
he says he supports the motion .
but he appreciates the concerns raised by mp , including those raised by george galloway , he says .
( the tory george galloway fan club - whose existence until today was unknown - seems to be expanding .
see 1.50pm . )
diane abbott , the labour mp , has not spoken in the debate yet .
but she told the today programme she would be voting against the government , and on the daily politics she restated her opposition to the government 's plans .
the images we 've seen of the beheadings and the massacres and genocide that isis is carrying out , have made a lot of people think we have to do something .
but i think a joint bombing operation with america will not crush isis .
in the end it 's a political issue , there 's not a western military solution .
the fact that iraq has asked us makes it legal which has to be a consideration .
but it 's not isil that 's threatening the integrity of iraq .
what has threatened the integrity of iraq is a corrupt and sectarian government which has driven sunnis into the arms of isil .
unless you fix that underlying political problem you will not get peace in the region .
the kurds will fight isil in the short-term but in the long-term they want a kurdish state , that involves dismembering not just iraq , but turkey and syria .
i 've taken the quote from politicshome .
anti-war protesters at westminster have erected a huge barrier at abingdon green , where broadcasters have set up camp for their live coverage of the debate .
norman smith ( @ bbcnormans ) anti war protest backdrop at westminster
i missed the speech from alistair burt , the conservative former foreign office minister , but , helpfully , he 's summarised it on twitter .
alistair burt ( @ alistairburtmp ) 1 i make 3 points in commons : daesh occupying land and minds ; each needs confronted ; legal force to end barbarity and challenging ideology .
alistair burt ( @ alistairburtmp ) 2 .
do not underestimate arab states confronting daesh ; profound statement against corrupt ideology/false claims to protect sunni communities alistair burt ( @ alistairburtmp ) 3 .
if daesh was fuelled by iraqi failures , so it was also by the atrocities of assad in syria .
must not lose sight of need to end conflict .
daesh is an arab term for isis that the french government has started using to avoid tarnishing islam with association with terrorism .

documents.title: ian austin 's speech
text: labour 's ian austin supports the motion .
but he says action in syria may be necessary too .
we should not give president assad a veto .
and president putin should not get a veto either , he says .

faced with a brutal and murderous organisation that has kidnapped and beheaded victims including british aid workers , which has carried out genocide , enslaves women , buried others alive , crucified , executed and literally butchered christians , yazidis and muslims - anyone who does n't share their warped and perverted view of islam - it presents a huge threat to the rest of the region and with an international coalition having been built in the region , i think it is right to confront [ isis ] .
i would like to ask : why we are being asked to approve air strikes in iraq but not in syria ?
i would like to ask why we welcomed and supported the american bombardment of [ isis ] targets in syria this week but said that british action should be limited to iraq ?
why , if we think the american action was legal , why action by britain would not be ?

i would like to ask what the difference would be between taking action against [ isis ] on one side of the border is from taking it on the other even , as we have heard , the border does n't really exist .
i think we should have acted sooner to support those amongst the rebels who want democracy and human rights when the revolution against assad started .
he says britain should have intervened earlier .
assad and isis are much stronger than they were a year ago , he says .
george galloway 's speech is now on youtube .
i 've posted the link at 1.14pm .
( you may need to refresh the page for it to come up . )
sir nick harvey , the lib dem former defence minister , is speaking now .
he has already summed up his case on twitter .
nick harvey ( @ nickharveynd ) case on iraq made : barbarous enemy , legal cover , credible ground allies needing air support .
but syria would be a totally different case !
here 's the full text of the archbishop of canterbury 's speech .
the debate also continues in the lords , where the prospect of future action against isis in syria is also on peers ' minds .

this intervention is from former labour defence secretary john hutton : mark d'arcy ( @ darcytip ) former def sec john hutton tells lords its inevitable that we will rethink position on syria - and shd not rule out using uk ground forces .

lord goldsmith was labour 's attorney general at the time of the 2003 invasion of iraq and advised that the action taken was lawful : mark d'arcy ( @ darcytip ) iraw war era atty-gen ld goldsmith says use of force in syria more difficult legally than iraq - but case can be made 4 self defence .

douglas hurd was the conservative foreign secretary during the first gulf war in iraq in 1990-91 : mark d'arcy ( @ darcytip ) in halting voice former foreign sec douglas hurd tells lords a terrible clarity has reaveled isis is a plague comparable to the black death .
frank dobson , the labour former health secretary , says he is minded to vote for the motion .
in other wars , women are raped and killed by accident .
isis use this as a tactic , he says .
and if it were not for the bombing that has already taken place , isis could have taken baghdad already .
nobody in this house , or anywhere else , can be certain the policies we are being asked to endorse will succeed .

if we look at the track record of the interventions of the french , the british and the americans in the middle east since the collapse of the ottoman empire then the odds look as though we wo n't succeed - everything else has gone wrong .
and yet i find myself probably going to vote for the motion tonight and the argument i would put is this : the situation we face is different from previous ones .

clearly what has happened is a threat to international peace and security and therefore entitles the world powers and the government of iraq to invite support to try to protect them against their invaders .
it may not be an invading army but it is certainly an invasion that iraq has suffered and iraq is entitled to call upon the rest of us .
they are faced by a genocidal outfit .

documents.title: sir alan duncan 's speech
text: sir alan duncan , the conservative former international development secretary , says he is backing the government .
as someone with 30 years ' experience of the middle east ( he was in the oil business ) , he says he came to the commons ready to warn mps to be cautious .
but , having listened to the debate so far , he realises that mps already recognise the need for this .
we are about to embark on something unlike anything we have seen before .
in my mind , it shows every sign of being neither easy nor conclusive .
when the falklands were invaded , force was obviously justified .
when kuwait was invaded , we were right to work with others to repel the aggressor .
in each case , we knew instinctively what the objective was and we absolutely knew when we had attained it .
but this is different .
i think we are justified in deploying our armed forces , both to fight vicious extremists and to support iraq 's request for help .
but the clear strategic objective for doing so and the manner in which we will use our weapons are much more difficult to shape than in the past .
we are living in an age that lacks the clarity of the past but that does not mean we do nothing .
he says the commons ' well of knowledge of the middle east is running rather dry .
mps should be wary of mocking george galloway , he says .
he says he thinks there may be a case for bombing isis in syria too .
but he also says that , if the strategy is not working , then britain should also be prepared to abandon the bombing , without shame , stain or blame .
the defence secretary , michael fallon , is currently on bbc radio 4 's world at one , discussing the ongoing commons debate over potential air strikes over iraq .
he told the programme : it 's a very different feel to the syria debate last year ¦ [ there is a ] mood of determination that we 've got to do something about isil .
he defended the proposed uk contribution of six tornado aircraft : militarily we certainly make a difference ¦ the americans have made it very clear they value the contribution we can make .
fallon added : you ca n't simply defeat [ isil ] by military action ¦ isil in the end has to be tackled on a broader front .
and he reiterated sentiments expressed by david cameron and foreign secretary philip hammond : there 's a strong case for action against isil in syria .
defence secretary michael fallon ( right ) and chief of the defence staff general , sir nicholas houghton ( left ) arrive for a cabinet meeting at 10 downing st on thursday .
leal-olivas/pa
the bbc 's nick robinson has summed up the nature of this debate very well .
nick robinson ( @ bbcnickrobinson ) debate on paper = uk military action v is in iraq .
commons will vote yes .
debate in reality = should syria be next ?
mood of real anxiety

labour mp fiona mactaggart , who is in the commons , has not decided which way to vote and is tweeting about her uncertainty : fiona mactaggart ( @ fionamacmp ) most mps clear bombing needed to stop isil .
last night constituents more unsure .
i not sure .
galloway makes me want to bomb , but what then ?

fiona mactaggart ( @ fionamacmp ) @ johnwoockmp , who unlike me knows how to vote today , says failure to build effective iraqui state following invasion creates duty to act now fiona mactaggart ( @ fionamacmp ) @ daviddurant if we listen to people in fear in iraq we will send bombers .
that would create temporary relief but would worse horror follow ?
labour 's ann clwyd says galloway was wrong to say al-qaeda were no present in iraq before the iraq war .
they were there , but under a different name , she says .
she says she supports the motion , but does not think it goes far enough .

documents.title: adam holloway 's speech
text: adam holloway , a conservative and a former grenadier guard , says that at sandhurst he was taught that military action should only be in pursuit of political goals .
but it is not clear what they are , he says .
he says you can divide isis into the good , the bad and the ugly .

i think when people in this house think of isis they think of a foreign fighter dressed in black holding before him a terrified offering dressed in orange , a kind of spectre or ghost screaming at us out of cyberspace .
well last week i was in iraq with the member for spelthorne [ kwasi kwarteng ] and an iraqi said to me you 've got to see isis in iraq like this - it 's the good , the bad and the ugly .
the good are the sunni tribesmen rising up against the sectarian government in baghdad .
the bad are the foreign jihadis and the ugly the former ba'athist regime people that might my regiment fought in the first gulf war .
now who 's going to kick the bad out ?
who 's going to kick the jihadis out ?
the only people on the ground who will be able to do that are the good and the ugly - the tribes and the ba'athists .
this is overwhelmingly a political problem , a security headache .
it 's not a first order clash between the west and the muslim world , but between neighbours .
he says having the mission described as an american-led one is counter-productive .
labour 's fiona mactaggart asks what holloway 's solution would be .
holloway says she solution is not a western-led military intervention .
action needs to be taken by regional players , he says .
there is no simple solution to any of this but the answer does not come from something military that is led by the west .
it comes from something political that is led by people within the region .
look , there 's a huge amount that we can do but mostly that should involve encouraging and enabling other people .
this should n't be a re-run of iraq in 1991 , where yes there was a big grand coalition of arab states but it was still led by the united states .
it should n't be 2003 either .
the lead for this if we are going to win should come from within the region .
it should include long-term political vision otherwise step by small step we are going to enter a much darker age of war and radicalisation .
if the west fails to morph into the background away from the military lead then i 'm afraid our vote today will be driving our nation towards disaster .

documents.title: george galloway 's speech
text: george galloway , the respect mp , is speaking now .
what a tangle web we have woven is abundantly clear to everyone watching this debate .
the mission creep has n't even waited for the end of the debate .
he says there is a consensus in the house that we will soon be bombing syria .
but the motion does not say that .
and there is a consensus that there will soon be boots on the ground .
the only question is , whose boots ?
this debate has been characterised by members of parliament moving around imaginary armies .

the free syrian army is a fiction which has been in the receipt of hundreds of millions of dollars , hundreds of tonnes of weapons , virtually all of which were taken from them by al qaida , which has now mutated into isil .
the iraqi army is the most expensively trained and most modernly equipped army in history .
hundreds of billions of dollars have been expended on the iraqi army , which ran away - leaving its equipment behind it .
isil itself is an imaginary army and a former defence secretary no less said we must bomb their bases .
they do n't have any bases .
the territory they control is the size of britain and yet there 's only between 10 and 20,000 of them .
do the maths .

they do n't concentrate as an army , they do n't live in bases and the only way a force of that size could successfully hold the territory they hold is if they have a population which is acting as the water in which they are swimming .
and that population is quiescent because of western policies and western invasion and occupation - that 's the truth of the matter .
isil could not survive for five minutes if the tribes in the west of iraq rose up against them .
labour 's ian austin asks if galloway really thinks women in iraq are quiescent with a force that buries them alive .
what galloway is saying is a disgrace .
galloway says : they do n't like it up em .
isil is a death cult , it 's a gang of terrorist murderers .
it 's not an army and it 's certainly not an army that 's going to be destroyed by aerial bombardment .
isil is able to rule the parts of iraq that it does because nobody in those parts has any confidence in the government in baghdad .
this will not be solved by bombing .
we 've been bombing iraqis for 100 years .
we have been bombing iraq for 100 years , he says .
in the 1920s we dropped chemical weapons on iraq , he says .
in 1930s we helped to kill their king .
labour 's emma reynolds asks what galloway 's solution is .
galloway says her intervention is asinine .
rory stewart , a conservative , asks the same question .
galloway says the solution is to help those already fighting isis .
this will not be solved [ by bombs ] .
every matter will be made worse .
extremism will be spread further and deeper around the world .
the people outside can see it , but the fools in here who draw a big salary and have big expenses can not .
addressing the question of what he would propose , he went on : we have to strengthen those who are already fighting isil .
we have to give them all the weapons they need .
the baghdad government has paid for weapons which have still not even been delivered .
we have to strengthen the kurdish fighters , who are doing a good job by the way in fighting isil .
has anyone in here seen a of [ the saudis ] fighting in syria ?
anyone seen a of a saudi jet bombing in syria ?
saudi arabia is the nest from which isil and these other vipers have come and , by the way , they do a fine line in head chopping themselves .
saudi arabia has 700 war planes - get them to bomb .
turkey is a nato member , get turkey to bomb .
the last people who should be returning to the scene of their former crimes are britain , france and the united states of america .
( i 've taken some of the quotes from politicshome . )

peter henley ( @ bbcpeterh ) isil will not be destroyed says george galloway `` we 've been bombing iraqis for 100 years - extremism will spread '' update : here 's the youtube video of galloway 's speech .
andrew mitchell , the conservative former chief whip and international development secretary , says the motion does not go far enough .
he says he is quite sure that the commons will have to return to this issue , so that it can back air strikes against isis in syria .
anyone who thinks this will be solved by bombing from the air is completely wrong , he says .

documents.title: pat mcfadden 's speech
text: in the commons labour 's pat mcfadden supports the motion , but says it is not clear why britain is not acting in syria too .
if the government can back military action by the us against isis in syria , why ca n't it take action itself .
i have to ask , as others have asked , why is it right to carry out such actions against isis in iraq but not in syria ?
the government has welcomed the action carried out by the united states and arab countries in syria in recent days .
if it is to be welcomed and right for others , why is it not welcome and right for us ?

and if the government 's position is that it is illegal or wrong to act in this way in syria , then why is it not illegal or wrong for the united states and those countries taking part in this action ?

militarily we have to ask ourselves what is the point of chasing isis from iraq through a barely-existing border to syria and morally we have to ask why is it right to come to the aid of the victims of isis who are living under a democracy in iraq but not those who are living under a dictatorship in syria .
the government 's motion is constrained by public opinion , he says .
but it should not spend too much time looking in the rear-view mirror .
it should back soft power with hard power , and will the means to finish the job .

is n't it the case that the motion before us is actually a reflection of where the country stands right now - somewhat limited in its confidence , over-burdened by past events , looking too much in the rear-view mirror ?
there are more quotes from the archbishop of canterbury 's speech here , at 12.18pm .
( as the debate goes on , i 'll be topping up some of the earlier posts , where i have quoted mps or peers using reported speech , with direct quotes from the press association wire .
to see these , you may need to refresh the page .
but it makes more sense to add the quotes like this , so that you can read the debate chronologically . )

documents.title: what happens next after a vote for air strikes ?
text: if , as expected , mps vote in favour of air strikes , the first attacks against islamic state ( isis ) targets in iraq could come within hours , reports the guardian 's defence and intelligence correspondent , ewen macaskill : the jets , based in cyprus , were out over iraq on wednesday night gathering intelligence in preparation for the attack an exercise that has been ongoing in the past month .
british special forces are already deployed to the region , primarily to gather intelligence and to help identify targets .
they are liaising with the 190,000-strong kurdish peshmerga , the main force on the ground engaged against isis in iraq .
six tornado jets are based at akrotiri , in cyprus , and that is seen within the mod as sufficient at this stage , a commitment that will not stretch limited resources .
in libya , the raf had 16 tornadoes in action and 10 typhoons .
also involved is an raf rivet joint surveillance plane , based in qatar .
an raf tornado gr4 aircraft flies into raf marham , in norfolk .
radburn/pa the six gr4-type tornado aircraft have been in cyprus for around six weeks ; they are usually based at raf marham in norfolk .
when taking part in any potential air strikes , they will come under the command of us centcom ( central command ) .
nigel dodds , the dup mp , says that northern ireland experienced terrorism , but that isis is even worse .
britain has a moral duty to help , he says .
sir nicholas soames , the conservative former defence minister , says he agrees with the points kenneth clarke was making .
labour 's dai havard says he understands the government 's case for military action .
but the government has been very bad at selling its plan to the public , he says .
the language is over ambitious , as it always is , in many regards about wars on terror and eliminating and destroying and so on .
here is more about justin welby 's speech in the lords .
tamara cohen ( @ tamcohen ) justin welby : religious leaders must `` up their game '' to draw people away from jihad .
but backs air strikes in short term # isil # lords steven swinford ( @ steven swinford ) archbishop of canterbury : we need to take this action now .

but is is also necessary that any response be undertaken on religious basis # isil steven swinford ( @ steven swinford ) archbishop of canterbury : in the here and now there is justification of the use of military force on humanitarian grounds # isil i 'll post full quotes when i get them .
liam fox , the conservative former defence secretary , tells mps that it has been obvious for some time that the iraqi government needs more air support .
he would go further , he says .
what i think we need to be clear about in this country is we can not disengage from the global threats that we face .
what is very clear to us is there are those out there who hate us , ideologically , for who we are , not what we do .
when the united states were bombing isil and we were delivering humanitarian aid they did not differentiate between an american hostage and a british hostage being beheaded .
terrorist ideology respects no borders .
there will undoubtedly be a cost of acting on this occasion but the cost of not acting would be infinitely greater .
but he says it is a mistake not to include syria in the motion , he says .
sooner or later we are going to have to do it .
it would have been far better if we had said so today .
comment is free is interested in readers ' views : should britain launch air strikes against isis ?

documents.title: archbishop of canterbury 's speech
text: in the lords justin welby , the archbishop of canterbury , is speaking .
he says that military action can be justified , and he says that in this case christians and others have asked for help .
the action proposed today is right we must not rely on a short term solution , on a narrow front , to a global , ideological , religious , holistic and trans-generational challenge .

we must demonstrate that there is a positive vision far greater and more compelling than the evil of isil such a vision offers us and the world hope - an assurance of success in this struggle - not the endless threat of darkness .
we will not be able to deal with a global holistic danger if the only weapons we are capable of using are military and administrative and we only focus on one place .
clearly , we do need to take this action now .

but it is also necessary over time that any response to [ isis ] and this global danger be undertaken on an ideological and religious basis , that sets out a more compelling vision , a greater challenge and more remarkable hope than that offered by [ isis ] .
update : here 's the full text of the speech .
sir menzies campbell , the former lib dem leader , says he is sure the proposed intervention is legal .
military action against isis in syria would be legal too , he says .

it has been suggested we need a united nations resolution before we could embark on anything of the kind now proposed in relation to syria , you have to accept the reality that the prospect of a united nations security council resolution is totally remote .
even putting one on the table would be a wholly pointless exercise because of the attitude undoubtedly to be taken by russia and possibly also by china .
( labour sources have been stressing that the party is not saying that there would have to be a un security council resolution for the party to back air strikes against isis in syria .
miliband said he would like one - see 11.23am - but this is not a pre-condition . )

documents.title: cameron and miliband 's speeches - summary
text: on the basis of the opening speeches , this is gearing up to be a high-quality debate ( which is not something that is always true of the house of commons ) .
david cameron and ed miliband 's speeches were measured and intelligent , and they both made a serious effort to engage with the arguments of their opponents .
and the interventions - which are often the most interesting features at this stage of a debate - were serious and sincere and ( apart from andrew bridgen - see 11.27am ) non-partisan .
the inteventions also revealed quite how much concern there is on the backbenches about this mission .
as norman smith has been arguing on the bbc , the enormous majority cameron will get at 5.15pm will not reflect the amount of unease felt about what cameron is doing .
here are the main points .
cameron has said that he thinks there is a strong case for britain also launching air strikes against islamic state in syria .
but , in his speech opening the commons debate , he said that he was not proposing that now because he wanted to act with consensus .
i do believe there is a strong case for us to do more in syria but i did not want to bring a motion to the house today which there was n't consensus for .
it 's better if our country can proceed on the basis of consensus .
he said he thought air strikes against isis in syria would be legal .
in this house there are many concerns about doing more in syria .
and i understand that .
i do n't believe there is a legal barrier because i think the legal advice is clear that were we to act or others to act there is a legal basis .
he said britain would be fighting islamist extremism for years .

even after isil has been dealt with , we should be in no doubt that future british prime ministers and future british governments , i suspect , will be standing at this despatch box , dealing with this issue of islamist extremism in different forms and in different parts of the world for many years to come .
isil has sprung up quickly but around the world we see the mayhem caused by other groups , whether that is boko haram in nigeria , al-shabaab in somalia , al qaida in yemen .
we are dealing here with a generational struggle caused by the perversion of one of the world 's great religions , islam .
he said britain 's support for the iraqi government was conditional on it defending and protecting all of your people , and that must include the sunnis in iraq as well .
he said britain wanted to support its muslim friends reclaim their religion .

we will play our part in destroying these evil extremists , we will support our muslim friends around the world as the reclaim their religion and , once again , our inspirational armed forces will put themselves in harm 's way to keep our people and our country safe .
labour leader ed miliband speaks to mps in the house of commons on friday .
photograph : /pa ed miliband cited robin cook - the leading labour opponent of the 2003 gulf war and a hero to the labour soft left - to justify his support for the motion .

the late robin cook said in his resignation speech on the eve of the iraq war : our interests are best protected not by unilateral action but by multilateral agreement and a world order governed by rules .
this is multilateral action prompted by a legitimate , democratic state .
and a world order governed by rules if it is about anything must be about protecting a democracy .
which is what this motion is about .
miliband said labour was supporting air strikes against isis in iraq because the proposal passed six tests he had for action of this kind .
military intervention had to : have just cause ; be a last resort ; be legal ; have a reasonable prospect of success ; have regional support ; and be proportionate .
he said labour had reservations about supporting air strikes against isis in syria .

nicholas watt , the guardian 's chief political correspondent , files this on the opening of today 's debate : david cameron has held out the possibility of extending british air strikes against the psychopathic forces of the islamic state from iraq to syria as he said there were no legal barriers to a change in the mission .

as he opened a lengthy commons debate to approve british military action in iraq with a warning that the campaign could last for years , the prime minister suggested he would be prepared to extend the military campaign without the initial approval of parliament in the event of a humanitarian catastrophe .
british prime minister david cameron leaves downing street on his way to the house of commons on friday morning .
tallis/afp/getty images the prime minister indicated that he had decided to limit british involvement to strikes in syria in the face of opposition from labour .
he told mps : i do believe there is a strong case for us to do more in syria .
but i did not want to bring a motion to the house today which there was n't consensus for .
it is better if our country can proceed on the basis of consensus .
in this house there are many concerns about doing more in syria .
and i understand that .
i do n't believe there is a legal barrier because i think the legal advice is clear that were we to act or others to act there is a legal basis .
but it is true to say that the syrian situation is more complicated than the iraqi situation .
it is more complicated because of the presence of the brutal dictator assad , it is more complicated because of the state of the civil war .
you can read the report in full here .

more from associated press on the announcement this morning that denmark will join air strikes against isis in iraq : the danish government on friday announced it was joining the coalition to strike at the islamic state extremist group , sending seven f-16 fighter jets to take part in airstrikes against the group in iraq .
britain and belgium are also debating their involvement in the coalition friday , while the netherlands has already announced it will take part .
the european countries do not plan to deploy in syria .
danish prime minister helle thorning-schmidt said her government would send four operational planes and three reserve jets along with 250 pilots and support staff .
the deployment will last for 12 months .
she urged other countries to participate , too .
no one should be ducking in this case .
everyone should contribute , she said .
a vote in parliament is planned and is considered a formality .
however , no date was immediately set for the vote .
danish prime minister helle thorning-schmidt addresses the united nations general assembly in new york earlier this week .
xiaolei/xinhua press/corbis
hazel blears , the labour former communities secretary , starts by asking mps to think of alan henning .
he lives near her in salford , she says .
she appeals directly to isis to release him and send him home .
he was there on a mission of mercy , she says .
she supports the motion , but she thinks it is minimalist .
she has no doubt we will have to return to this again , she says .

kenneth clarke , tory mp and former cabinet minister , is speaking from the backbenches : patrick wintour ( @ patrickwintour ) ken clarke says uk mil effort largely symbolic , but will give uk positive influence on future diplomacy over proxy struggle iran & saudi .

documents.title: kenneth clarke 's speech
text: kenneth clarke , the conservative former minister , and one of the tories who voted against the iraq war in 2003 , is speaking now .
there is a clear legal case for action in iraq this time , he says .
but he says previous military interventions have created a situation at least as bad as what occurred before , he says .
he says he will support this motion .
but we are the early stages of working out where we are going .
our contribution is almost symbolic , he says .
i am left with the feeling that certainly i should support this motion because some of our best allies are taking part in this intervention .

but i still think we 're at the early stages of working out exactly where we 're going and i do think that our almost symbolic participation in these military attacks - six aircraft and our intelligence are no doubt valuable to our allies - but we 're symbolically joining with them .

the main hope i have is it gives us a positive influence on the diplomacy and the unfolding politics that have to take place to try to get together what again seems to be agreed on all sides is necessary - the widest possible participation and settlement between the great powers of the region in order to get what we all want , lasting stability and security in what at the moment is a very dangerous region of the world .
peter hain , the labour former cabinet minister , is speaking now .
he set out his reasons for supporting the motion in this guardian article for comment is free .
paul waugh ( @ paulwaugh ) hain 1st to hit wmd klaxon .
`` i was wrong we went to war on a lie '' more than most , maybe haunted by spectre of robin cook edm raised earlier
mps listen as labour leader ed miliband speaks in support of military action against isis in iraq .
john bercow , the speaker , says 77 mps want to speak in the debate .

he calls the first backbench speaker , sir richard ottaway , the conservative chair of the commons foreign affairs committee , who backs the motion , but asks why there is hesitating about bombing isis in syria too .
he concludes saying he supports the government with trepidation .
associated press reports that denmark is to join the coalition to fight isis in iraq , and will send seven f-16 fighter aircraft .
the uk is proposing to send six raf aircraft .
alistair bunkall ( @ alibunkallsky ) uk 's fighter jet contribution is the same as belgium and nl , fewer than denmark , france and australia , and of course us .
miliband quotes from what the late robin cook said in his speech in 2003 opposing the iraq war .
cook said international problems should be solved multilaterally .
that is what is happening now , he says .
the guardian video team has put together this take on david cameron 's speech to the commons , opening today 's debate : david cameron outlines his argument for military intervention in iraq .
miliband says he wants to explain why this is different from 2003 .
first , britain is supporting the iraqi government this time .
second , the action is legal .
third , there is no prospect of negotiating with isis .
this is a last resort , he says .
fourth , this has international support .
and , fifth , britain is not committing ground troops .
miliband says he wants to address the concern that intervention could make things worse .
he understands the argument , he says .
but he does not agree .
he says a divided iraq would be more of a threat to the uk , he says .
and it would be difficult for the uk to persuade arab countries to get involved if it does not get involved itself .
labour 's tom clarke says in the past the international community was condemned for tolerating genocide in rwanda and sudan .
that is why the public support this motion .
miliband says he agrees .
labour 's jim sheridan asks if miliband will put as much effort into getting a satisfactory solution in palestine .
miliband says he supports the two-state solution .
a small group of protesters has gathered on abingdon green , outside the houses of parliament , to express opposition to the proposed air strikes .
protesters outside the houses of parliament as mps debate whether the uk should join air strikes against isis .
kitwood/getty images
miliband says any action must be proportionate .
he thinks that has been met in his case .
this is not a clash of civilisations , he says .
miliband says in any action , there must be just cause .
there is in this case , on humanitarian grounds , and on the national interest .
isis territory could be a haven and training grounds for terrorist action against the uk .
miliband says that isis can not be negotiated with .
labour 's kevin brennan asks if miliband thinks we have a duty to help because of the iraq war .
he voted against that , he says .
miliband agrees .
some people say that because we intervened in 2003 , we should not intervene this time .
miliband says there is a case for saying the opposite , because that intervention contributed to the problems .
andrew bridgen , a conservative , says this is another case , like the deficit , of the coalition clearing up the mess left by labour .
miliband says that intevention does him no credit .
faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) oh dear backbench mp raises the deficit in question to miliband .
aside from that , it 's been a highly creditable debate so far .
the labour party has tweeted out the full text of miliband 's speech he is , in fact , still delivering it , having given way to interventions by several mps .
here 's the link .
despite the tone of consensus in the debate so far , there are mps who have doubts about the wisdom of embarking on air strikes .
andrew listed some of those who intend to vote against the motion here .
many are concerned about so-called mission creep and the intractable problem of syria : allegra stratton ( @ bbcallegra ) miliband : `` isil is murdering muslims '' .
key argument for labour mps very worried about supporting this .
not even sure this persuades them .
nick robinson ( @ bbcnickrobinson ) huge contrast between commons debate today & in 2003 .
wave of scepticism from tory right & lab left re mission creep & likelihood of success
robert halfon , a conservative , asks if labour would support air strikes against isis in syria .
miliband says labour would consider any proposition .
but he has three concerns .
first , would it be legal ?
if britain were intervening in syria , it would be better to have a un security council resolution .
second , there is the issue of ground forces .
in iraq , the iraqi army can fight isis .
but who would do that in syria ?
and , third , it is not clear what the routemap is in syria to the change that cameron wants .

documents.title: ed miliband 's speech
text: ed miliband is opening his speech .
there needs to be a a comprehensive strategy , he says .
isis is not simply another terrorist organisation , he says .
on 15 august isis fighters separated the men from the women and children of one village , drove the men away and killed them .
the women and children were taken prisoner , he says .
isis is killing muslims , he says .
and muslims recognise that .
he quotes british muslims saying they are perpetrating the worst crimes .
ed miliband , labour and opposition leader , is speaking now .
ed miliband responds to the prime minister .
/bbc
cameron is winding up now .
this is not 2003 , he says .
we must not use past mistakes as an excuse for indifference or inaction , he says .
we will support our muslim friends around the world as they reclaim their religion .
and he says we must support the armed forces .
labour 's liz kendall asks what is being done to stop countries buying oil from isis ?
cameron says the un has taken action on this .
isis is selling oil to assad , he says .
alok sharma , a conservative , asks what more can be done to cut off funding from isis .
cameron says isis have oil , and in some towns in northern iraq they just took money from the banks .
zac goldsmith , a conservative , says britain needs to take a tougher stance on countries like kuwait that have been funding extremists .
cameron says countries need to realise the threat posed by extremism .
labour 's jim cunningham asks if cameron would have another vote if he wanted to deploy ground forces .
cameron says he has said he would come back to the commons if he wanted to extend air strikes to syria .
but , with ground troops , he does not think that would be the right thing to do , he says .
james gray , a conservative , says the motion has been worded to attract maximum support .
but is n't there a case for leadership , he asks .
is there not a place here for leadership and statesmanship rather than popular support of the country .
he needs the support of the country but do we really need a vote ?
cameron says we live in a robust democracy .
the commons expects to have its say .
he supports that convention .

cameron 's statement that he would be prepared to take action in the face of urgent humanitarian need and then come to parliament for support has prompted some questions : paul waugh ( @ paulwaugh ) cam causes much muttering w warning he 's prepared to order further mili action + then come back to parliament for approval .
hain spots it that 's a reference to peter hain , labour mp and former cabinet minister , who asked another question relating to syria .
tim shipman ( @ shippersunbound ) cameron says he would act without permission of parliament to prevent a massacre .
good .
dan sabbagh ( @ dansabbagh ) cameron says in response to hain he would act in syria to contend with a humanitarian emergency ahead of a commons vote .
is this legal ?
cameron says , even after isis has been dealt with , future british governments will be dealing with the threat posed by islamist extremists for many years to come .

even after isil has been dealt with , we should be in no doubt that future british prime ministers and future british governments , i suspect , will be standing at this despatch box , dealing with this issue of islamist extremism in different forms and in different parts of the world for many years to come .
isil has sprung up quickly but around the world we see the mayhem caused by other groups , whether that is boko haram in nigeria , al-shabaab in somalia , al qaida in yemen .
we are dealing here with a generational struggle caused by the perversion of one of the world 's great religions , islam .
but i have no doubt that this struggle is one which this house and this country is more than equal to .
cameron says isis are a bunch of psychopaths who have perverted islam .
the snp 's mike weir asks if all kurdish leaders want military intervention .
cameron says that the kurdish leadership do want britain to intervene .
labour 's peter hain asks if cameron said he would act first , and come to the commons later , in the event of a humanitarian emergency .
it should be the other way round , he says .
cameron says hain heard him right .
cameron says he supports the convention that the commons votes on premeditated military action .
but he reserves the right to act first in an emergency .
julian huppert , the lib dem mp , says cameron has ruled out troops on the ground .
but the motion is carefully worded , and does not quite say that .
would there be any personnel on the ground .
cameron says the motion is ruling out the deployment of british combat troops .
