this from labour mp stella creasy , who is in the commons : stellacreasy ( @ stellacreasy ) @ bbcnormans : `` there is n't a walk on by option '' - pm < powerful physical jolt this phrase just created across parliament

on his way to the commons this morning , labour leader ed miliband spoke to reporters and ruled out british ground troops being committed in iraq , saying the uk must not repeat the mistakes of the past : labour leader ed miliband discusses possible military strategies to combat isis in iraq ahead of the commons vote on friday .
cameron says he would be prepared to order immediate military intervention if he thought that was necessary to avert a humanitarian catastrophe .
in those circumstances , he would come to the commons later for approval .
a packed house of commons debates supporting military actions against isis .
cameron says there is no question about the legality of this mission .
a summary of the government 's legal advice has been released to mps .
cameron reverts to his list of questions that need to be answered .
does the uk need to take part ?
yes , he says .
it has capacity that other countries do not , such as the brimstone missile , which even the us do n't have .
we have our unique surveillance and intelligence capabilities .
we have highly professional forces which are well used to working with their us counterparts .
these are some of the reasons why president obama made clear to me that america wants britain to join the air action in iraq .
but i believe it is also our duty to take part .
caroline lucas , the green mp , says it be better to get iran and saudi arabia involved , and to look for diplomatic solutions .
cameron says he met the iranian president this week .
labour 's david winnick says this could last for years .
cameron says isis have already declared war in us .
there is n't a walk-on by option , he says .
not all of labour 's front bench back the stand by opposition leader ed miliband to rule out strikes against syria .

as my colleagues nicholas watt and randeep ramesh reported this week : jim murphy , labour 's international development spokesman , said air strikes in syria to destroy isis would not be illegal as washington does not recognise the legitimacy of president assad .

quizzed at a fringe meeting [ at the labour party annual conference ] on syria , organised by humanitarian aid charities worldvision and islamic relief , murphy told delegates that air strikes are part of the answer .

when he was pressed over whether dropping bombs in syria would be legal given the regime in damascus has refused permission for foreign jets to strafe isis positions , murphy replied : america has said that they are not seeking assad 's [ permission ] .
they do n't recognise assad .
it 's important that america is trying to stop the humanitarian slaughter with air strikes .
the labour party is not opposed to trying to save people 's lives .
murphy was demoted last year from his position as labour 's defence spokesman to the post of shadow international development secretary after he expressed unease over miliband 's stance on syria .
last year , the government was defeated on taking military action in syria after labour refused to support cameron 's stance .
after the vote , murphy claimed that labour mps , including himself , had not wanted to rule out military action in syria and the party had not expected the vote 's outcome .
it 's not what i wanted , he wrote on his blog .
cameron says that , to beat isis , the international community has to build the capability of those opposing them .
the iraqi government needs more assistance .
it has asked for help .
the real work of destroying isis will be done by the iraqi security forces , he says .
but britain can help .
bob ainsworth , the labour former defence secretary , asks if the iraqi government has the will do defend sunni areas .
cameron says he is having this conversation with the iraqi government .
the new prime minister does represent a change , he says .
britain should give the iraqis help , but make that conditional on you defending and protecting all of your people , and that must include the sunnis in iraq as well .
nadhim zahawi , a conservative , asks if the iraqi prime minister said he did not want ground troops .
and what about the sunni tribes ?
cameron says the iraqi prime minister was very frank about needing britain 's help .
and the sunni tribes need to see they can be part of a successful iraq .
julian lewis , a conservative , asks what other arab states are doing .
will they offer sunni ground forces ?
cameron says britain needs to tread carefully .
the iraqi government is supposed to represent sunnis , shia and kurds .
it should be representing all of its people , not getting proxies to do it .

many mps are intervening to question how syria fits into the government 's proposal ; the motion debated today specifically excludes syria from the air strikes under discussion : this motion does not endorse uk air strikes in syria as part of this campaign and any proposal to do so would be subject to a separate vote in parliament .

allegra stratton ( @ bbcallegra ) commons packed for recall but most interventions from mps about syria even tho vote limited to just iraq otherwise would n't get through nicholas watt ( @ nicholaswatt ) pm suggests no legal barrier to extending air strikes to syria .
@ twitterid says us legal advice 'robust ' paul waugh ( @ paulwaugh ) cameron : '' i do n't think there is a legal barrier '' to uk military action in syria .
v signif .

hints miliband the real obstacle krishnan guru-murthy ( @ krishgm ) the debate - mostly about syria - shows how the very limited ambition of uk strikes in iraq only addresses half the problem , or less .
cameron says he did not want to bring a motion to the house that would not attract consensus .
he wants britain to proceed by consensus .
the syrian situation is more complicated than the iraqi one , he says .
but there is a strategy for dealing with syria .
what syria needs is what iraq needs - a government represents all people .
john baron , a conservative , says air strikes could be counter-productive , especially if isis says it has been able to withstand an assault from the us .
cameron says he does not accept that .
lives have already been saved by air strikes , he says .
claire phipps ( @ claire phipps ) cameron : isil needs to be destroyed in syria as well as iraq ¦ but it 's better if our country can proceed on the basis of consensus
cameron says britain is supporting a genuinely inclusive government in iraq .
and it wants a transition in syria .
as part of this , the british military has a role to play .
labour 's john woodcock asks what can be done to change the government in syria .
cameron says syria needs an inclusive government .
britain has backed the moderate opposition .
he thinks iran has a role to play in encouraging better government in both iraq and syria .
the jury is still out as to whether this will happen .
alistair burt , a conservative former foreign office minister , says the us is giving weapons to the free syrian army .
will britain do this too ?
they need help , he says .
cameron says britain has given them advice , mentoring and non-lethal equipment .
he is not proposing to change that today .

this is from the guardian 's data editor , alberto nardelli , on public support for air strikes : alberto nardelli ( @ albertonardelli ) a similar number in france ( 59 % ) and britain ( 57 % ) are in favour of military intervention against isis according to polls by ifop and yougov
cameron turns to his next question .
is there a comprehensive plan ?
yes , he says .
the government is taking action to tackle extremism at home .
preachers of hate have been banned , he says , and action is being taken against people spreading extremism .
but there has to be action to tacke extremism abroad .
labour 's dennis skinner intervenes .
how long will this last ?
and what will be done to stop mission creep ?
cameron says he is not proposing committing ground troops .
and he will address the mission creep issue later .
labour 's hazel blears asks if cameron will support muslims in the uk who are standing up to extremism .
yes , says cameron .
edward leigh , a conservative , says we armed the iraqi army .
but they ran away from isis .
does cameron think he can tackle this by air strikes alone ?
cameron says he is certainly not saying that .
i am not claiming that by air strikes alone we can roll back this problem .

what this problem requires is a comprehensive strategy , including a well-formed iraqi government and well-formed iraqi armed forces because they in the end will be the ones who have to defeat this on the ground .
but where i disagree with you is the cause of how this came about .
i would say that the two most principal causes of this problem as i have said - there is the background of islamist extremism .

but the two principal causes are the fact that in syria assad has been butchering his own people and acting as a recruiting sergeant to the extremists , and secondly that in iraq we had a maliki government that did not represent all the people of iraq .

i thought in one of the most powerful interventions i have heard him make , ban ki moon got it spot on when he said that , look , missiles can kill terrorists , but it is good governance that will kill terrorism .
we should have that thought front and back of mind as we debate this afternoon .
john redwood , a conservative , asks if cameron is satisfied that the iraqi government has a strategy to win over sunnis .
cameron says he agrees it must unite shia , sunni and kurd .
it has not happened yet , but it is happening now .

the commons is packed for the opening of the debate : norman smith ( @ bbcnormans ) george galloway just rushing into commons for iraq vote stellacreasy ( @ stellacreasy ) debate starts - lots of concern to see british govt work with muslim groups in uk and even pm praises @ twitterid change f # walthamstow
david cameron opens the debate .
/bbc

documents.title: david cameron opens the debate
text: david cameron is now opening the debate .
the question before the commons is what role britain should play in fighting isis ( which he calls isil ) , described by president obama as the network of death .
there is no more serious question for the commons than deciding whether to commit the armed forces to action , he says .
he outlines various questions that needs to be addressed .
first , is there a threat to the uk ?
yes , he says .
there have already been attacks in europe .
isis is a terrorist organisation unlike any we have seen before .
their brutality is staggering .
their methods belong to the dark ages .
but they have modern weapons , they have taken territory the size of the uk and they are making millions from oil .
this is not a threat on the far side of the world .
left unchecked , we will face a terrorist caliphate on the shores of the mediterranean , bordering a nato member , with a declared and proven determination to attack our country and our people .
this is not the stuff of fantasy - it is happening in front of us and we need to face up to it .
john bercow , the commons speaker , opens by taking a vote by acclamation on a business motion allowing today 's vote to go ahead .
there is a five-minute limit on backbench speeches in the debate .

documents.title: mps voting against the motion
text: here are some mps who have said they will be voting against the motion .
( i will top this list up as the day goes on and more mps confirm they are voting against .
paul flynn ( labour ) paul flynn ( @ paulflynnmp ) cameron falls into isil 's trap of provoking west into a conflict that they hope will lead to global war .
vote no graham allen ( labour ) harry cole ( @ mrharrycole ) graham allen agrees rt @ twitterid : ukip wd oppose air strikes in # iraq .

`` you ca n't beat is just by aerial bombing '' says @ twitterid farage diane abbott ( labour ) norman smith ( @ bbcnormans ) diane abbott confirms she will vote against air strikes in # iraq @ twitterid4today caroline lucas ( green ) caroline lucas ( @ carolinelucas ) killing people rarely kills their ideas : my thoughts on # iraq debate via @ twitterid

documents.title: commons debate - timings
text: the commons debate will start shortly .
here are the timings .
10.30am : david cameron opens the debate after some brief procedural business .
around 11am : ed miliband responds .
after that the debate continues through the day .
11.30am : peers open their debate on the issue .
here is the list of peers who intend to speak .
around 4.20pm : douglas alexander , the shadow foreign secretary , winds up for labour .
around 4.40pm : nick clegg , the deputy prime minister , winds up for the government .
5pm : mps vote .
the result will be announced at about 5.15pm .
i will be covering the opening speeches in detail , and other speeches is slightly less detail , according to how interesting they are .
and my colleague claire phipps ( @ claire phipps ) will be helping out inserting some reaction as the debate goes on .
a yougov poll out this morning suggests that 57 % of voters support air strikes against isis .
as the yougov analysis points out , this figure has risen markedly in the last month .
public support for air strikes against isis .
dragana haines , widow of david haines , the aid worker who was taken hostage and beheaded by isis earlier this month , has spoken about the imminent possibility of british airstrikes .
she told sky news : i do support british military air strikes but limited to distinctive targets .
no changes in such societies can be enforced , they have to come from within .
yesterday , haines ' daughter , bethany , told itv news that isis ought to be eradicated : they ca n't be doing this to people and get away with it .
no matter what nationality , if they 're western or not .
hundreds of syrians have been killed by them and they need to be stopped .
britain has a duty to respond to isis , says david haines ' daughter .
the labour mp barry sheerman says philip hammond was worryingly unconvincing in his today interview this morning .
( see 9.48am . )
barry sheerman mp ( @ barrysheerman ) philip hammond worryingly unconvincing on uk involvement in iraq & syria @ twitterid4today
ed miliband is briefing labour mps ahead of the vote .
toby perkins mp ( @ tobyperkinsmp ) heading into briefing with @ twitterid miliband and @ twitterid on motion to support uk airstrikes against isil in iraq

documents.title: hammond hints that british air strikes could extend into syria later
text: philip hammond , the foreign secretary , has been giving interviews this morning ahead of the opening of the vote .
as i said earlier , he said the government could ask parliament to back air strikes against isis in syria at a later point .
here are the key points from his interviews .
hammond said that britain 's initial contribution to the bombing campaign , six raf tornados , was probably adequate at this stage but that it could later be expanded .

the plan is to provide air support to the iraqi government alongside our allies , the united states , france and an increasing number of european and arab countries who are going to take part in this operation .
it 'll get bigger if it needs to get bigger .
i think the question first of all will be identifying targets through intensive intelligence gathering and surveillance and then as targets are identified and confirmed , prosecuting them .
i think six tornadoes is probably adequate to do that in the early stages , it may need more later on .
he said the government could support air strikes against isis in syria at some point in the future .
in fact , he implied this was likely .

asked about the prospect , he said : if we felt that we had some capability to contribute , that was needed in order to deliver the outcome that we all want to to see , which is the defeat of isil , then we would certainly make the case for doing that .
but the government has insisted that this would not happen without a second commons vote .
he said he thought the american legal case backing air strikes against isis in syria looks robust to me .
but he said the uk government had not taken detailed legal advice on this issue yet .
he said the government was ruling out putting combat troops on the ground , partly because it would be counter-productive .
we 're not going to put british combat troops on the ground for two reasons .
first of all , we do n't think it would make sense ; you ca n't combat an extremist islamist insurgency by putting western troops on the ground - that simply feeds their narrative .
ground fighting has to be done primarily by iraqis ; if they need help , the help has to come from neighbouring muslim countries .
i 've taken the quotes from politicshome .
labour has not signed the iraq motion ( see 9.23am ) , but ed miliband has confirmed this morning that his party will support it .

in a clip for broadcasters he said : i am not going to make predictions but we will be supporting action against isil in iraq today in the house of commons , because isil is a murderous organisation that threatens the stability of iraq , the region and are a threat to our national interest .
i want to reassure people there is no question of uk ground troops being committed and in acting against isil we are part of a coalition including with countries in the region .

documents.title: the commons motion - full text
text: for the record , here is the full text of the motion that mps will be voting on .
its title is : iraq - coalition against isil .
( the motion uses isil - islamic state in iraq and the levant - as the acronym for islamic state , although it 's guardian house style to use the alternative acronym , isis . )

that this house condemns the barbaric acts of isil against the peoples of iraq including the sunni , shia , kurds , christians and yazidi and the humanitarian crisis this is causing ; recognises the clear threat isil poses to the territorial integrity of iraq and the request from the government of iraq for military support from the international community and the specific request to the uk government for such support ; further recognises the threat isil poses to wider international security and the uk directly through its sponsorship of terrorist attacks and its murder of a british hostage ; acknowledges the broad coalition contributing to military support of the government of iraq including countries throughout the middle east ; further acknowledges the request of the government of iraq for international support to defend itself against the threat isil poses to iraq and its citizens and the clear legal basis that this provides for action in iraq ; notes that this motion does not endorse uk air strikes in syria as part of this campaign and any proposal to do so would be subject to a separate vote in parliament ; accordingly supports her majesty 's government , working with allies , in supporting the government of iraq in protecting civilians and restoring its territorial integrity , including the use of uk air strikes to support iraqi , including kurdish , security forces ' efforts against isil in iraq ; notes that her majesty 's government will not deploy uk troops in ground combat operations ; and offers its wholehearted support to the men and women of her majesty 's armed forces .
mps will today vote on whether britain should conduct air strikes against islamic state ( isis ) .
in some quarters , this is being seen as the launch of a third iraq war in 25 years .
actually , the comparison is not exact .
for a start , unlike the last two , this is not a campaign against the iraqi government .

the british government wants to join the us and other international allies in helping the iraqi government defeat the islamist extremists who have used the syrian civil war to establish a powerbase in syria and who now control a chunk of northern iraq .
and war is not necessarily the most appropriate term .
the british government is explicitly ruling out committing ground troops to the operation , and in the immediate term all that is envisaged is a bombing strike involving six raf tornado jets .
still , it 's an important moment .
as the guardian reports , michael fallon , the defence secretary , says the campaign against isis could last two to three years .

and philip hammond , the foreign secretary , told the today programme that although today 's vote will just authorise air strikes against isis in iraq , in the future the government could ask parliament to back air strikes against isis in syria .
the us is already bombing isis targets in syria , and hammond said that the legal argument the us is using to justify air strikes in syria looks robust to me .
why is the british government only planning air strikes in iraq at this stage ?
because david cameron , the prime minister , does not think the commons would vote for military action in syria .

last year cameron tried to get mps to back an air strike against syria 's president assad , after the use of chemical weapons on the civil war , but he suffered a surprise defeat that contributed to washington also abandoning plans to bomb assad .

as the guardian splash reports , cameron has spent weeks now ensuring that that does not happen again and today 's motion has been carefully crafted to ensure that it has the support of labour , the main opposition party .
that 's means we wo n't be getting any knife-edge drama today .
when the vote comes , the only real interest will be whether the government majority will be more than 300 , more than 400 or more than 500 .
but during the debate we should learn a bit more about the government 's long-term plans for fighting isis .
and we 'll discover just how much opposition there is to the government 's plans .
cameron will open the commons debate shortly after 10.30am , and mps will vote at 5pm .
there will also be a debate in the house of lords , starting at 11.30am , but peers wo n't be voting and i 'll be focusing mainly on the commons .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .
